senses.de: To make something known in public or official way
senses.ex: The government announced a new tax plan.

Tips.title: Public Announcement
Tips.description: Used when revealing information to a broad audience, often through media.
Tips.example: The company announced its merger in a press conference.

Tips.title: Official Matters
Tips.description: Often used by authorities or organizations to disclose official information or decisions.
Tips.example: The mayor announced the new citywide curfew starting next week.

Tips.title: Expect Formality
Tips.description: Typically formal and used in serious or significant contexts, not casually.
Tips.example: The school board announced the new principal to the teachers.

senses.de: To tell people something is going to happen
senses.ex: They announced their engagement to their friends.

Tips.title: Personal News
Tips.description: Used for personal milestones or upcoming events in one's life.
Tips.example: After dinner, they announced their plans to move abroad.

Tips.title: Impending Events
Tips.description: Indicates something is scheduled to happen soon, often building anticipation.
Tips.example: The organizers announced the event lineup for the festival.

senses.de: To say something in a loud and clear way
senses.ex: The flight attendant announced the arrival time of the flight.

Tips.title: Audible Clarity
Tips.description: Emphasizes clear and often loud verbal communication.
Tips.example: The tour guide announced each stop with enthusiasm.

Tips.title: Attention Capturing
Tips.description: Aims to grab the listener's attention, especially in noisy environments.
Tips.example: The train conductor announced our arrival at the station.

senses.de: To introduce a television or radio show or a person who is performing
senses.ex: He announced the next song on the radio program.

Tips.title: Media Introductions
Tips.description: Common in broadcasting to introduce content or people to the audience.
Tips.example: Before the break, the host announced the upcoming guests.

Tips.title: Setting the Stage
Tips.description: Used to prepare the audience for what or who is coming next in a program.
Tips.example: The DJ announced the next track, creating excitement in the crowd.

Broadcast.wordDefinition:
Announce means to tell or make known something to a specific group of people, while broadcast refers to a message or program that is sent out to a larger, more general audience through news outlets or media channels.

A news station might broadcast information about a hurricane approaching a city to a wider audience. This information is important for anyone in the area and not just a specific group.

Announce is typically used for a specific group of people, while broadcast is for a wider audience.

Declare.wordDefinition:
Both announce and declare mean to make something known or public.

Declare typically has more serious implications and is used when something is being stated in an official or legal sense.

For example, a president might declare a state of emergency during a natural disaster.

Announce is used in a wider range of settings, while declare is typically used in more official or serious situations.

Disclose.wordDefinition:
Disclose is used to mean revealing or making something private or secret known. For example, a government might disclose classified documents, a celebrity might disclose personal information or a doctor might disclose a patient's medical history.

Announce is used when something new is being shared publicly, while disclose is used when something private or secret is being revealed.

Impart.wordDefinition:
Impart means to convey or share something, usually knowledge or information.

It is often used in a more informal or personal context, such as a conversation or a lesson. For example, a teacher might impart knowledge to their students or a friend might impart advice to another friend.

To summarize, announce is used to make something public or official, while impart is used to share knowledge or information in a more personal context.

Proclaim.wordDefinition:
Proclaim is used for bigger, more important things like declarations, statements, or claims. For example, a politician might proclaim a new policy or law, or a religious leader might proclaim a message or belief.

Announce is used more for practical or informational purposes, while proclaim is used more for grand, significant statements.

Publicize.wordDefinition:
Publicize means to promote or advertise something to the public in order to gain attention and interest.

For example, if a company wants to inform its employees about a new policy, it will announce it at a staff meeting. If the same company wants to advertise a new product to the public, it will publicize it through various marketing channels such as social media, billboards, and TV commercials.

Reveal.wordDefinition:
Reveal means to show or disclose something that was previously hidden from view or unknown. This can be used in a less formal or more dramatic situation, such as when a magician reveals how they did a trick or when a secret is revealed in a movie.

Announce is used when conveying information in a straightforward and factual manner, while reveal is used to add a sense of intrigue or surprise to what is being shown or disclosed.

State.wordDefinition:
State means to express something using clear and precise language in a formal way.

A government may state its policies on a particular issue in a formal document such as a constitution or law.
